dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clogged with doughy tourists bulging out of their bathing suits. A long line of cars waiting to park snakes out onto the main road. In the distance, we HEAR the persistent sound of a STUCK CAR HORN getting louder. A BRAND NEW BMW barrels past the line of waiting cars. Steam billows from its severely dented grill. With no regard for anyone, the Beamer swerves in front of an old lady and skids to a stop across the last two handicap spaces. JIM SIMMERS (38) calmly exits the vehicle and begins to peel off his robe and pyjamas one piece at a time as he marches towards a trash can. He’s down to his underwear as he snatches a newspaper out of the PARKING ATTENDANT'S hand and buck naked by the time he squats into the trash can to take a shit. It’s a scene, man. He’s folded in half, ass submerged in the trash can, knees dangling over the side. Jim flips to the sports page, seemingly unaware of the slack-jawed GAWKERS crowded around. The STUCK CAR HORN in the background is accented by a short GRUNT of relief as Jim finishes. He struggles to get out of the can, then pushes past the horrified crowd, bee-lining for the ocean. Naked as a jaybird, he strides purposefully into the cold waters of the Atlantic. The wailing CAR HORN rises in CRESCENDO as we...

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: If you accept it, then it’s over.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: So, what? I do what exactly?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: You take that bitch by the love handles and fuck the cash out of her. (off their looks) Fuck you guys, it’s a metaphor.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Mongo’s right. He’s fucked up, but he’s right. You gotta march right into that White Man’s office and demand your promotion.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yeah! You earned that shit, and shit. Jim looks at Blake. Blake has it all. And doesn’t deserve any of it. Jim knocks back his shot.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: You know what? You guys are right, you're absolutely right. That promotion is mine! He pounds the bar in emphasis.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Fuck Blake and fuck The White Man. Tomorrow I’m gonna march into that office and take what’s mine! INT. JIM’S BEDROOM - MORNING The dog barks, Jim awakens with kick-ass in his eyes.  21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight motherfucking raspberries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim reads his morning affirmation with extra special sauce.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (into mirror) You can have it all, Jim Simmers. But he can’t. EXT. JIM’S APARTMENT - MORNING The four-legged cocksucker rushes Jim, but Jim beats him to the car. Victory!

dialogues.speaker: THE GAY NEIGHBOR
dialogues.text: (calling out as Jim drives off) Sorry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim waits for the signal while others don’t. For a split-second, he looks around as if he might... Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An insane BLACK HOBO rants. He’s the only black person on Cape Cod. Above him TWO MUNICIPAL WORKERS fuck around with a power line.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK HOBO
dialogues.text: This Earth is not fit for man! Only in the afterlife can one find truth and justice. Come all ye faithful, joyful and triumphant, join me! Let go of this Earth and join me... The Black Hobo pulls out a toy pistol and puts it to his head. He sees Jim pull up in his Sporty Kia Spectrum (with racing stripe). Jim gets out and heads toward the store.  22.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK HOBO
dialogues.text: You! Dolemite! Join me! Jim speeds up but the bum rushes him.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK HOBO
dialogues.text: Join me and I will complete your training. With our combined strength we can end this destructive conflict and bring order to the galaxy. (suddenly lucid) I know why you’re unhappy. Jim stops.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK HOBO
dialogues.text: This is not your Earth. You can never find justice here amongst the wicked, but fear not. The afterlife awaits you. True heaven. True joy. Jim stares at the magical Negro and senses truth in his words. This is what he’s been waiting to hear.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK HOBO
dialogues.text: The big payoff is coming.

dialogues.speaker: ABOVE THEM --
dialogues.text: The Municipal Workers rear back, trying to avoid a severed, flailing power line. But Jim is too riveted by the Hobo to notice the wire. Or the puddle of water he’s standing in.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK HOBO
dialogues.text: (with zealotous zeal) The big payoff is coming and-- (suddenly terrified)

dialogues.speaker: OH, SHIT MUTHAFUCKA
dialogues.text: The Bum jumps back as the wire makes contact with the water and fries Jim alive.

dialogues.speaker: AN EMPTY VOID
dialogues.text: Jim stands in space. Nothing above him, nothing around him.  23.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Where am I? (realizes) Oh, my God. The black bum was right. Jim smiles in a way we’ve not seen before. True joy.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Come. Come take me... Jim falls to his knees, arms beckoning upward like Shawshank Redemption. Long beat.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I’m ready, um, Lord, or whoever. Hook me up. Jim looks out, still Shawshanked...absolutely nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Come!

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND JIM --
dialogues.text: A magnificent tunnel of light opens up, beckoning... But Jim is still looking forward, clueless as always. He stands.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Really? The light behind him grows even more magnificent’er. If only he’d just turn around...

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: No? (then) I don’t even get this? Seriously! No pearly gates? I’ve waited for so Goddamn long...I mean, I’m not damning you, but come on! EVERYTHING SUDDENLY GOES BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim explodes into consciousness. The Black Hobo is pounding on his chest.  24.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK HOBO
dialogues.text: Don’t you die on me, man. You’ve never backed away from a fight in your life! Jim tries to push the Bum off. A COP CAR PULLS UP. The Black Hobo punctuates each word with a head slap.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK HOBO
dialogues.text: Say you, say me! SAY YOU, SAY ME! The COPS rush the bum. They snatch him away. Jim stands up. Groggy. The bum breaks free and does a flying kick into Jim’s chest.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK HOBO
dialogues.text: Don’t die on me! The Cops pin the bum down. Handcuff him. One of the COPS steps to Jim.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Are you okay, sir? Jim looks down. His feet are smoldering. His mind reeling.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: No. (looks up to heaven) I’m really, really disappointed. INT. JIM’S LIVING ROOM - TIME LAPSE Jim lays on the couch submerged in a bout of existential depression. OUTSIDE HIS WINDOW the sun goes up and down as the world turns. Days pass, Jim doesn’t move, half asleep, half awake. Finally, he sits up.

dialogues.speaker: REAL TIME
dialogues.text: Jim picks up the remote with a sigh. Turns on the TV. THE TELEVISION is suddenly alive with Tom Cruise.

dialogues.speaker: TOM CRUISE
dialogues.text: (from “Mission: Impossible”) Jim? The image JUMPS forward to an anguished close-up.  25.

dialogues.speaker: TOM CRUISE
dialogues.text: Why, Jim? Why? That’s weird. Jim switches the channel. Low and behold... THE TELEVISION offers more Tom Cruise on this channel.

dialogues.speaker: TOM CRUISE
dialogues.text: (from “Jerry Maguire”) Help me. Help me help you. Help me help you! Jim switches the channel. And again...

dialogues.speaker: TOM CRUISE
dialogues.text: (from “All The Right Moves”) Doesn’t this seem just a little bit too crazy?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes, it does. Jim changes the channel. THE TELEVISION won’t stop. It’s like Tom Cruise is speaking directly to Jim.

dialogues.speaker: TOM CRUISE
dialogues.text: (from “The Color of Money”) It’s like a nightmare, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: This is nuts.

dialogues.speaker: TOM CRUISE
dialogues.text: Man, it just keeps getting worse and worse, doesn’t it? Jim hits the remote. And there he is again, in tight close-up.

dialogues.speaker: TOM CRUISE
dialogues.text: (from “Days of Thunder”) When I’m driving, I got a guy on the radio who talks to me. I can’t see him but he talks to me.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: So what’s your point? The image FREEZES. Jim changes the channel.  26.

dialogues.speaker: TOM CRUISE
dialogues.text: (from “Cocktail”) What does it mean? NOTHING!

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: That much I figured out on my own. Click.

dialogues.speaker: TOM CRUISE
dialogues.text: (from “Magnolia” ) In this big game that we play - LIFE - it’s not what you hope for, it’s not what you deserve...it’s what you TAKE! The image FREEZES. Jim stares for a long moment, trying to process the universe’s code. He hits the remote one last time...

dialogues.speaker: TOM CRUISE
dialogues.text: (from “Risky Business”) Sometimes you just gotta say what the fuck. Make your move. The television’s holy glow takes us to... INT. JIM’S LIVING ROOM - NEXT MORNING SUNLIGHT. The barking dog wakes Jim. He gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls out his penis with his hand and steadies it to shoot pee out of the tip. It’s a magnificent stream, powerful after days of build up. When droplets hit the seat, Jim ignores them and moves on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim pulls out his cereal, his juice, his raspberries and his fiber additives. He looks at his boring breakfast, turns to the freezer and grabs a vat of ice cream... Jim spoons it from the carton as he walks out.  27. INT. JIM’S LIVING ROOM - MORNING He stands before the mirror, shoveling ice cream into his maw at an alarming rate. He stares at his reflection for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: What’s the point? Jim tosses the half empty carton of ice cream over his shoulder and moves on. EXT. JIM’S HOUSE - MORNING Jim exits the house lethargically, dragging his backpack behind him. Within seconds, that asshole dog is upon Jim, snarling and barking like the asshole he is. Jim doesn't slow, doesn’t acknowledge the dog in any way. Just proceeds to his sporty KIA (with racing stripe) and climbs in.

dialogues.speaker: THE GAY NEIGHBOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Come back here, Hoagster! Bad Hoagie! That’s a bad Hoagie. The dog continues to snap and snarl as Jim cranks “THE REFLEX” and pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same scene, different day. Jim’s sporty KIA slows to a stop. “THE REFLEX” continues to blare even as a carload of judgemental TEENS pulls up beside him. They laugh at Jim. They laugh at his gay music. Some even point at him while they do it. Teens can be so cruel. So cruel. But it doesn’t affect Jim in the least. And he’s done waiting at this stupid light. He steps on the accelerator and zooms away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cute Clerk babbles away on the phone as Jim makes his way to the magazine rack. Grabs himself a copy of LOOSE & JUICY magazine and proceeds to the counter.  28. The clerk sees Jim, punches some buttons on the Lotto machine. Jim shakes his head, ‘no.’ Opens the magazine to the centerfold and holds it up. The clerk is horrified. Jim tosses some bills on the counter and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Workers gather around as Blake shows off the brand new BMW M-3 that he bought with his promotion bonus. Olivia is particularly impressed. As Jim walks by, disgusted, Blake winks and shoots him the gunpoint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim chucks his backpack into his cubicle as he heads for the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pauses when he sees people crowded around the broken coffee machine. Drops his head exasperated, then... Looks up to the empty coffee room on the second tier. Decides.

dialogues.speaker: STAIRWAY TO THE SECOND TIER
dialogues.text: As Jim ascends the stairs, his CO-WORKERS gawk.

dialogues.speaker: CO-WORKERS
dialogues.text: (fearful) What’s he doing? / He’s crazy! Jill rushes over to stop him but freezes at the first step. She doesn’t dare set foot on it.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: (looking up at Jim) Jim, come back! You can’t go up there! But Jim keeps going.  29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Olivia stands alone, shocked to see... Jim walking right toward her. He takes the creamer out of her hand, then grabs the entire pot of coffee and walks out. Olivia squints, piqued by Jim’s robust flavor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim pours a cup, adds his cream, and leaves the gourmet coffee for the rest of his co-workers. They gather around the pot, sniffing it like wine.

dialogues.speaker: CO-WORKER
dialogues.text: Smell the aroma. Jill pours a small sip. Swirls it around in her mouff.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Oh, my God...no clumps.

dialogues.speaker: CO-WORKER 2
dialogues.text: And it doesn’t taste like mud. INT. JIM’S CUBICLE - MORNING Jim has his headset on, leaned all the way back in his chair, talking to a customer...

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (into headset; flat, emotionless) I’m trying to help you, ma’am but you’ve got to answer the question, okay? How fat are your kids? While the person on the line yells Jim twirls his chair, waiting for his turn to speak. He notices Jill in her cubicle, talking to a customer on the phone as she applies the final touches to a pencil sketch.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: (into phone) Yes, sir, I’m checking for you right now. She holds it up for Jim to see.  30.

dialogues.speaker: THE DRAWING
dialogues.text: revealing a realistic rendering of Jim joyfully feeding Blake into a meat grinder.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: spins away in his chair, offering no reaction.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: ..-Ma’am...okay, sorry, sir. Sir, I understand, but “husky” isn’t a medical diagnosis. Jill sighs, breaks out her eraser and changes the smile on drawn Jim’s face to a frown.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I need a number... What do I mean? Like combined do your twins weigh more than your car?...Offended? Sorry. Please, just give me a number... (almost falls out of his chair when he hears the number) You're fucking kidding me. How much? (awed Are they like, seven feet tall? No? (punches his keyboard) Well, I’m looking at the actuarial table now and unless your twins are LeBron James and Shaquille O'Neal, they ain’t gonna qualify. (interrupts the customer’s rant) Hold on--hold on--hold on, I just gotta ask this. I mean, there’s no way on earth any reputable firm is gonna insure those orcas of yours, but I feel the need to ask to satisfy my own curiosity. Why’d you ever marry a fat chick? Click. Jim takes off the headset. Leans forward, despondent. His phone rings incessantly.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (behind him) Hard day, huh? Jim looks up. Blake drops a load of files on his desk.  31.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Make these a priority.

dialogues.speaker: WE STAY WITH BLAKE
dialogues.text: as he struts through the office, finger pointing and being obnoxious. He slaps Jill’s ass then takes a donut out of CO-WORKER 2: THE SPAWNING’S petite hand. After one bite, Blake tosses the donut and heads upstairs. BLAKE’S OFFICE - SECOND TIER - CONTINUOUS Blake enters and is shocked to see... Jim standing there with the files.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Um... Jim holds out the files and drop kicks them...papers fly all over the room. Jim gives Blake the gunpoint...

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Fuck yeah I did. ...and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful. Right on the water. The sound of heterosexual sex emanates from inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything about this place says “old money”, including the old money lady, MAUREEN, being pounded from behind by Larry. Larry’s face is curled in disgust, tears streaming down his cheeks. And yes, he does indeed have a clothespin on his nose.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: (near climax) Oh, yes! Oh YESSS!!! Fucky me Lenny! Fucky me like you need a job!  32. Larry punches a pillow in olfactory agony. Without warning, A MAN appears in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Shit! Larry pulls out, grabs the lamp from the night stand defensively. Maureen stays right where she is.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Jim? Is that you? Yep. It’s Jim.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I need to talk to you, Larry. Now. Larry is torn. Money on the bed, friend in crisis.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Seriously, I need to talk.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: That’s it. Mood ruined. She grabs a robe and heads to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While Jim talks, Larry steals. He rifles through drawers and jackets.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I think I’m having a meltdown, Larry.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Watch for Maureen.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I died--I saw the other side and there’s nothing. Larry holds up a diamond watch.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (re: the watch) Too personal? Yeah. (sets it back down) Is the shower still running?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Are you paying attention, man?  33. Larry notices a big ass change jar and starts stuffing his pockets. He freezes when Maureen enters, wearing only a towel. An awkward beat. Errant coins slip from his fists.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Um, Jim, can we deal with your meltdown later?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Are you joking? All the times I’ve picked you up when you were drunk, or bailed you out of jail? You can’t listen to me for five goddamn minutes?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (whispers) I’m kinda working here, Jim. Jim throws Larry against the wall and digs through his pockets. Pulls out a pirate’s booty.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: You’re not working. Why don’t you just tell her instead of stealing! Man-up and sell your cock with some respect. Maureen isn’t even slightly phased.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: What? You think his stealing is news to me? I leave this crap out on purpose. (slaps Larry’s ass) Go ahead. I’11 take a rain check. Larry nonchalantly pockets the watch. Jim just shakes his head. INT. JIM’S CAR - LATER Jim drives aggressively. Larry leans over to check the speedometer.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Did you really die and shit? Jim grabs one of his melted shoes from the back seat, drops it into Larry’s lap.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: What do you think?  34. Larry stares at the shoe.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: These cost like ninety--

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: That’s not the point!

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: The point is: there is no point. There’s nothing, man. Some people have it all, and some people have shit. He pulls up to Rob’s house.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I have shit. INT. ROB’S GARAGE - DAY Rob is in his garage cleaning dried blood off of his hooks and spiked clubs. Larry and Jim enter.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Whoa! That’s sick!

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: (proud) Yeah, I designed it for the new guys on the job. Nothing worse than seeing some noob half-spiking his club in a wounded harp seal’s head without making the kill shot. It’s almost cruel. Larry notices an instructional poster on the wall detailing the proper way to kill baby seals.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I don’t know how you do it, Rob. How can you look into that cute little face and smash it. How do you smash their adorable little faces off?

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Hey, I’ve gotta support my family. And you know what, it’s racist against cows to care about harp seals.  35.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (vexed by that fucked up sentence)

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Cows are thinking creatures too, but no one minds killing them. Why are harp seals so special? (off the guys’ faces) Cows make great pets and they’re very protective unlike harp seals that have a horrible side no one ever sees.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (dead serious) Come on, Rob. Don’t try to justify your murder by player hating on harp seals. They don’t hurt anyone and shit, you do!

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: You're out of your element, short bus! You wouldn’t believe what I’ve seen those creatures do. I’ve seen that white fur covered in blood...and not always their own. Before it can turn into an argument, Jim jumps in.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Enough! Silence.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: No more fighting about baby harp seals. You guys don’t seem to understand, there’s no God, there’s no heaven, there’s nothing! All we get is this! And for me, this-- this whole thing--everything...it’s been a waste!

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: He died and now he’s getting all--

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: What do you mean he died.  36.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I was electrocuted. I saw the other side and there. Was. Nothing!

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Um...

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Look, these rules that we live by, they’re meaningless. Why not grab a woman by her tit and tell her you want to fuck her?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I do it all the--

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Shut up, Larry. Why have any restraint at all? Why not do whatever you fucking want, whenever the fuck you want, cuz ultimately it doesn’t matter at all...THERE’S

dialogues.speaker: NO FUCKING PAYOFF...TO ANY OF IT
dialogues.text: MONSTROUS GROANS rumble from inside the house. Rob instinctively tightens his grip on the club. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: (staring at the walls) You're scaring Junior. (then) You need to calm down...

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (calmly) No. Fuck no. I don’t need to calm down. I have spent my entire life “calming down.” From here on out, I’m getting what I want.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Um, what is it? What do you want? Jim grabs a sharpie and writes on the wall... 1. . That jes.” 2. "That car” 3. “That chick”  37.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (as he writes) I want that promotion. I want that Beamer that Blake bought with that promotion. And you know what? I wanna fuck Olivia. I wanna fuck her in the ass. The guys are quiet, mesmerized by Jim’s new outlook. Just then, Rebecca enters with a plate of fresh baked cookies...and two black eyes.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: (sing-songy) Who wants cookiiieees? Larry reaches for one, burns his hand...too hot.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: And I want those. Jim grabs a handful of cookies.

dialogues.speaker: ARGHH
dialogues.text: Melty chocolate that would normally be delicious scalds Jim’s hands. But he pounds them down, disintegrating his mouth with abandon.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Oh, god!

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Dude, wait till they cool--

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Fuck that...ARRG! Jim eats damn near every one, his face clenched in agony.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Maybe you could leave this last one for somebody else. Jim snatches the last cookie off the plate and belligerently smashes it all over his face before he eats it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The office is dark, shut down, except for one room.  38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim holds a list, picking through the infinite rows of files. He drops the ones that match into a basket. Jill enters.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: This better be good, you calling me in here at midnight. He hands her the basket.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (terse) Verify that all contact information in these files is current.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Do I work for you?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Didn’t mean to be curt, I’m just really focused right now. She flips through the files.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: These are all Blake’s clients.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: What are you up to, Turbo?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Taking back what’s mine. EXT. MR. WHITEMAN’S HOUSE - BACKYARD - DAY A barbecue for all the people who matter is in full swing. Brie cheese, fine champagne, and stiff upper lips abound. Schooley and McCorkle are off to the side, doing what they do...

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOLEY
dialogues.text: .--holy shit, your fist must have smelled like ham salad.  39.

dialogues.speaker: MCCORKLE
dialogues.text: Still does. I’ve been soaking my hand in tomato juice for two weeks and it still reeks like spoiled cock-garbage. McCorkle holds out his hand. Schooly leans in, takes a long whiff and instantly recoils from the stench.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOLEY
dialogues.text: Holy Jesus! That smells just like my dream. Meanwhile, at the center of the party, Blake has a crowd of rich folk entranced.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: .-.-and I’ve got a little poem that I’d like to read in honor of this occasion, if I may. He unfolds a slip of paper and begins to read.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: “It’s easy to grin, when your ship comes in, and you’ve got the stock market beat. But the man worthwhile, is the man who can smile, when his shorts are too tight in the seat.” The crowd laughs haughtily. Blake’s unearned popularity is mind-numbing. Olivia stands off to the side, stunning and bored. Mr. Whiteman’s WIFE pats Blake’s head like a good dog.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MR. WHITEMAN
dialogues.text: So entertaining...and popular too. I’ve always thought you’d fit in nicely. Blake’s moment in the sun is dashed when...

dialogues.speaker: TRACY, A FOUR-FOOT TALL, 300-POUND ADOLESCENT, ENTERS
dialogues.text: LIKE A TASMANIAN DEVIL, screaming and stealing food from everyone and slamming it into her face.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: (between bites) BANNH! Spicy bean burgers...BORPH!  40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim and Rob escort a number of other obese, crippled, and differently-abled people into the backyard. Mr. Whiteman approaches, outraged.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WHITEMAN
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing? Who are these people...what are these people? In the background, Tracy chases down a woman with a plate of ribs.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: BAAARRG! Jimme more meat sauce!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Olivia and Mrs. Mr. Whiteman watching from afar.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MR. WHITEMAN
dialogues.text: What in blazes is wrong with that horrible child?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: (bored) If I had to guess, I’d say Prader- Willi syndrome.

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: flattens the woman with a backside clothesline. OLIVIA NODS.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Yep, that’s Prader-Willi, alright.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MR. WHITEMAN
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: It’s a rare genetic disorder that causes compulsive eating and irrational behavior. TRACY eats the ribs off the ground, screaming to the sky like a victorious predator.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO JIM AND MR. WHITEMAN
MR. WHITEMAN
dialogues.text: Explain, Jim. Now!

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: These are your policy holders. I thought you should meet the people your company has been paying millions of dollars in claims to. Jim grabs BLINDY, a fifty-year-old wheezing blind man with an oxygen mask over his face.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: This is Blindy, he--

dialogues.speaker: BLINDY
dialogues.text: (rasping) Trevor. My name is--

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: This is Blindy Trevor. He's... (reads Blindy’s file) Twenty-three-years-old with absolutely no history of health problems. Yet as you can see, he’s at least fifty, blind as a bat and suffering from advanced emphysema. Mr. Whiteman squints. Outrage gives way to “tell me more.”

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: as he exits the house, zipping up. He spots Jim with Whiteman...this can’t be good.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Hey! Blake rushes over. Wedges himself between Jim and Mr. Whiteman.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: How dare you, Jim Simmers. This is a private function on private property and you are specifically not invited. Now pack up these mongoloids and get--

dialogues.speaker: MR. WHITEMAN
dialogues.text: Quiet, Blake. Don’t say another word. (to Jim) Continue...  42. Jim points to a woman (FRANCESCA) in an overturned wheelchair. She feebly attempts to fight off... TRACY, who violently yanks at a candy bar that has somehow gotten tangled in Francesca’s hair.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: And that is Francesca. Look at her...

dialogues.speaker: TRACY
dialogues.text: Mounds! Mounds! JIMME MOUNDS! Tracy can’t get the candy bar out of Francesca’s hair, so she starts gnawing on the crippled woman’s bouffant.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Get it off me! Get it off me!

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: (to Jim) Jim?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Not yet. (hands Mr. Whiteman a file) On paper, Francesca is twenty four years old, never been sick a day in here life, and makes her living as a lifeguard.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Oh GOD! It HURTS!

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: But as you can see, she can’t swim. She can’t possibly swim. Tracy drags Francesca by her hair. Francesca flails, trying to cling to her wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WHITEMAN
dialogues.text: Get to the point, Simmers.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: The point is that you have been defrauded, Mr. Whiteman. By one of your own employees. Stunned faces all around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as they survey Tracy’s path of destruction.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MR. WHITEMAN
dialogues.text: My god. How do we stop her?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: You can’t. She can’t help herself. Mrs. Mr. Whiteman sighs, shakes her head as she regards the collection of misfits on her lawn.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MR. WHITEMAN
dialogues.text: Goddamn circus people. Olivia shoots her a chastising look and moves toward the action. STAY WITH Mrs. Mr. Whiteman as she plucks the olives from her martini glass and pops them into her mouth. Just as she’s beginning to chew... WHHHUMMP! Tracy knocks her to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVES AND POPEYE
dialogues.text: Tracy, her face a deep brown smear of chocolate and hair, grabs Mrs. Mr. Whiteman by the ears and tries to forcibly suck the pre-chewed olives from her mouth. Mrs. Mr. Whiteman manages a MUFFLED, HIGH-PITCHED SCREAM... +..one that only Mr. Whiteman can hear. He cocks his head like a dog, then turns to see his wife under retarded assault.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WHITEMAN
dialogues.text: (panicked, to Jim) For the love of god, call off that creature! Rob remains standing with his hands behind his back.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Rob? Rob unclenches his hands, revealing a baseball bat tight in his grip.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: (with a gleam in his eye) I’m on it. Whiteman watches Rob move to save his wife. He turns back to Jim.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WHITEMAN
dialogues.text: Who has dared defraud me? OFFSCREEN, we HEAR a series of horrible “THWACKS”, punctuated with pained cries from Tracy.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: Now is not the time for this discussion, sir. I mean, your wife is being mauled by a four hundred pound goonie bird. Perhaps we should--

dialogues.speaker: MR. WHITEMAN
dialogues.text: Didn’t I tell you not to speak? (to Jim) I want names.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (indicating the retard army) Why don’t you ask them...

dialogues.speaker: MR. WHITEMAN
dialogues.text: Well speak up. Who sold you your policies? One by one, they all say the same thing... “Blake Henderson.” Mr. Whiteman is aghast.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WHITEMAN
dialogues.text: (to Blake) Henderson is this true?

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: No--well, yes, but not really. Kind of. It’s very complicated... Jim hands his stack of files to Mr. Whiteman.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: It’s all right there. The White Man levels his cold blue eyes on Blake.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WHITEMAN
dialogues.text: Blake, you’re fired.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: But I--I’m the most--what about my popularity?  45.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WHITEMAN
dialogues.text: Get out. Blake looks at Jim, gives him the gunpoint.

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE
dialogues.text: I...I never thought you had it in you. Blake skulks off. Whiteman clasps Jim on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WHITEMAN
dialogues.text: I guess you’re my man now, Jim Simmers. Congratulations. He walks Jim into the heart of the barbecue. The crowd embraces him. Olivia moves to his side. Jim takes the glass of champagne from her hand and gulps it down...just like he’s gonna do her in a few days. WE PULL BACK, past a table where...

dialogues.speaker: ROB HAS TRACY PINNED FACE DOWN --
dialogues.text: knee in her back, caressing her face with the tip of his bat, gently cramming cake down her gullet. Tracy squirms, Rob enforces the pin, whispering...

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Shhh. Shhhhhhhh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in SLOW MOTION as Jim enters the office like a rock star. Jim nods to his former co-workers who gaze upon him in awe. High fives are slapped. Jim gives the “you know it” nod to all those who are now beneath him.

dialogues.speaker: HE GETS TO THE STAIRS --
dialogues.text: Pauses. Looks back at the adoring crowd. A single tear in his eye. As Jim takes that first monumental step towards true happiness, the crowd erupts in applause.  46.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (sotto; heartfelt) Today, I win. I win it hard. Jim climbs to the top of the stairs. He absolutely MUST give them one last parting glance. EVEN SLOWER MOTION as Jim looks down, not at his fans but at his defiant erection. His hard, hard defiant erection. He sticks it out for the crowd below, just a little bit...but enough. Goddamn he has gusto.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: SUPER: “45 Minutes Later...” INT. JIM’S NEW OFFICE - DAY A palatial high tech office dominated by a huge oak desk, a big screen TV and a wet bar. Jim is slumped in his chair, miserable. The phone is ringing, the files before him sit unaddressed. He doesn’t even have his kick ass boner anymore. Without warning, Rob and Larry barge in followed closely by JIM’S NEW SECRETARY.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Look at these digs. This place is fucking opulent and shit.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry sir...these men DO NOT have an appointment and I....

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (to Secretary) They’re fine, Cindy. Leave us.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Simmers. She leaves. Rob prowls the office like a kid ina candy store.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: This office is incredible, man.  47.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (without enthusiasm) Yeah. Rob crosses to the big screen.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Holy shit! Is that a fifty-inch?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Sixty. Larry spies the Johnnie Walker Blue label at the wet bar.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Johnnie Walker Blue? GODDAMN, that shit is almost as good as Johnnie Walker Green! Can I have some?

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: The Blue is better than the Green.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: No it’s not. Can I have some?

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Yes it is. Right, Jim?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Look fool, everyone knows the Green is the best. Cuz it costs more. Can I have some, Jim?

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: How do you figure?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: What color is money, man? Ipso facto, motherfucker... Rob just shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Can I have some...?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Take it.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Take the Blue? Like all of it?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Take the whole bottle. I don’t care.  48.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: What’s wrong with you, man? I mean, you’ve got the sweet office, the Johnnie Walker blue...you’re living the life now, man.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I dunno. It seems like it should be...better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bar is empty except for our guys. Jim has a mean buzz going.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Man, I don’t know any other job that let’s you get drunk in the middle of the day. A WAITER steps up. Drops off a few beers.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (to the waiter) Hey, what’s the most expensive drink in this place?

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: This is a dive bar, dude.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Come on, what’s the most expensive drink you’ve ever served? The Waiter thinks for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Well, some rapper from New York was once in here, throwing his black rap money around. He ordered...what was that...oh yeah, he ordered a Long Island Iced Tea made with all top shelf liquor.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Perfect. We'll take six.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: I’m gonna need a deposit on that.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: . (tipsy) NO! No. Jim, no.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: It’s okay, Larry. Jim pulls out a credit card. As he’s handing it to the waiter, Larry snatches it. Inspects it.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Holy shit...company credit. That shit’s gangsta. The Waiter grabs the card from Larry and heads to the bar. Jim drops his head, frustrated with everything.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Bargh.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Bargh? Why bargh? You’re in the game now. You’re checking off the list, man. In a year or so you’ll be able to afford that car, and--

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: A year? Fuck a year. I got enough in my savings to buy that car now. Outright.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Out-motherfucking-RIGHT!

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: You can’t spend your savings on a car, Jim.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Why? Why can’t I do it?

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Because it’s just not done. Savings are--they’re for...later.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I personally have conclusive fucking proof that there is no later. Sometimes, you just gotta say I don’t give a fuck--

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: --and steal a bitch’s money.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (nodding) Sometimes you’ve got to go large or stay at home.  50. Rob has no idea what he’s talking about. But Larry does. He and Jim bump knuckles.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Players do what they want to, suckers do what they can.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: FUCKIN’ A RIGHT! That! That right there... (points into Larry’s mouth) That’s what I’m talking about. The Waiter arrives with their drinks in tall, precious glasses. Jim grabs his, downs it, wipes his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Let’s do this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fleet of shiny Beamers and our three guys. Rob is cradling four sloshing Long Island Iced teas in his arms, staining everything in his vicinity. Larry holds a small BRIEFCASE while trying to eat a scalding pizza, too drunk to understand that it needs to cool. Jim has an even meaner buzz going. When the CAR SALESMAN comes over, Jim glares at him.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: (thick country accent) Hey, ya'll. Looking to buy or just lookin’? The Salesman looks behind him, unable to comprehend why Jim is glaring so viciously. Rob hands Jima drink.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (points at a car) I want that silver M-3, right there. How much?

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s a beaut’. It’s fully loaded, ya’ll. I reckon.  51.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Look, no pitch, this is gonna be the easiest sale you’1l ever make. How much?

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: Well, now, lemme just tell you’n what this here lil’o jewel gots under the hood. The Salesman is getting progressively more country with each exchange.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I’ve got cash. How much?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yeah, how much?

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: Well, as I’m sure you’n alls knows, the Beamer M W is not for the common, man. But, now, I wouldn’t reckon you is--

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: How. Much?

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: Well, that’d all depend. You see, this one here, that you’se is gazing upon, this one’s the Tiger Edition. It’s got double aluminum crank shafts and--

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I don’t care. How much?

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: I’m sure you wanna know what you’re gettin’. And what you’d be gettin’. While the Salesman talks, Jim grabs the briefcase and cracks it open. It’s full of cash.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: ...-I mean, one might mosey on down to the hoosegow with a big ole posse’a desperados and commence to demanding all kinds’a things, I reckon. But don’t mess with Texas, that’s where I’d be hailin’ outta, ya know--  Silence. that he price. 52.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Why won’t you answer?

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: Sir, I see you're serious--

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: NO! That’s not an answer. A proper answer is a number. A number that will allow me to hand you this cash and drive off with that car.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: But, now don’t get yer dander up, cowboy. I’m gonna lay down the statistics--

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Motherfucker! How much is the car? You’re in the business of selling cars! Just give me a price. The Salesman seems to finally have grasped needs to shut the fuck up and give Jima

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: Hey now, I’m here to work with you. We got different financing options that a fella such as yerself may want to choose from.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Different from a briefcase full of cash? The Salesman’s mouth moves, but he can’t form a sentence that is a direct answer. Rob rolls his eyes, grabs a slice of pizza, peels off the cheese and slams it sauce-first into the Salesman’s face. The molten sauce scalds him and sets him screaming.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: PRAAAAAHHHHHHH-YA‘LL!!! Rob kneels beside the writhing Salesman and begins peeling off another piece of pizza.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: (whispers ) How much?  53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys are packed in, riding in style. Jim fiddles with the stereo as he drinks and drives.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (to Rob) What the hell got into you back there?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yeah, you went all Vietnam or some shit, like that salesman was a freakin’ harp seal or something! Rob squints, trying to process what he just did.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: The dude was wasting our time.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Yeah but it cost me an extra two grand to keep him from pressing charges.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Like you say, sometimes you just gotta say, who the fuck cares, right?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I don’t. I don’t care about shit!

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Button it, Rainman. You’d have to understand to care. Jim swerves, irked that his radio sucks...

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: This stupid car doesn’t have satellite! (looking back) How can this be the ultimate driving machine and not have satellite? All of a sudden, Jim comes up on tail lights. He hits the brakes.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: What the--  54. EXT. MID-CAPE HIGHWAY - “SUICIDE ALLEY” - NIGHT A TWO LANE STRETCH OF HIGHWAY with flexible plastic pylons going down the center. Jim’s new beamer is being cock-blocked by a FAMILY OF TOURISTS driving half the speed limit. Nothing but open road in front of them. INT. JIM’S BMW - CONTINUOUS Jim rides the tourists’ bumper.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Oh, my God! He hits the horn.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: I don’t get it. The speed limit is 65, why is this douchebag driving 40 miles an hour?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: You know, the speed “limit” isn’t the speed “requirement.” It’s the limit. It’s the fastest you’re allowed to go. So really, this guy is just choosing not to ride at maximum capacity.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Yeah, but there are also speed minimums. It’s as unsafe to drive slow on a highway as it is to drive fast.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: No. No, Rob. No. Slow is always safer.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: You’re a retard, just like my boy...but without the strength.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Did you just call your stepkid a retard? Robert gulps the last drop of the last Long Island.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Fuck yeah I did. Cuz he is.  55.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Whoa.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Look, there’s no harm in calling a spade a spade as long as you appreciate the spade.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (serious as a heart attack) You’re a goddamn racist, man. And it sickens me. Jim has had enough. He pulls into the center of the road to pass - the pylons strike his Beamer - THWACK!

dialogues.speaker: THWACK
dialogues.text: An oncoming car forces him back into his lane.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Hey, be careful man. Those pylons--

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I know what I’m doing. No stupid plastic pylons gonna hurt The Ultimate Driving Machine®.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yeah, but some of them...

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I do whatever I want. All the time.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yeah, but... Jim lays on the horn, pulls back into the center of the road. THWACK!! THWACK! THWACK!

dialogues.speaker: SHKA-BANG
dialogues.text: The Beamer strikes a SOLID pylon, mangling the grill. The car horn WAILS, stuck. Steam wafts into the atmosphere. As the car limps to the breakdown lane...

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Some of them are filled with concrete. A beat.  56. Until Rob bursts out in a fit of uncontrollable laughter.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: HAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAH you fucking asshole HAHAHAHAHAHAHA! Whatever. Jim jams the car into gear. He stabs at the radio switching stations.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Goddamn analog radio. Goddamn everything. Goddamn every fucking molecule in the goddamn world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From off in the distance we hear it. We hear it coming... The horn. Jim’s new newly fucked up Beamer pulls in front of the house, horn blaring. The back door opens. Before Larry can set both feet on the sidewalk, Jim tears off. Larry shakes his head. Sighs. Digs a clothespin from his pocket, clamps it on his nose, and walks to the front door. EXT. ROB’S HOUSE - NIGHT We see the silhouette of Rob’s massive son, standing on the roof, screaming at the moon. Not howling, screaming...

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: Moon! Mooocoocooon!!! His screams meld with the sound of... Jim’s car horn. The beamer pulls up. Rob gets out. Jim tears off and leaves his friend to face his son. Alone.

dialogues.speaker: MOOOOOOON
dialogues.text: Junior turns away from the moon and locks eyes with Rob. He squints, ‘oh, yeah, it’s on.’  57. Rebecca comes out with a roll of tape. Rob holds out his hands so she can tape his knuckles. INT. JIM’S HOUSE - NIGHT Jim enters. Tosses his keys. Heads straight for the bedroom. INT. JIM’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Sleep eludes him as Jim stares at the ceiling, contemplating his fate.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: INT. JIM’S BEDROOM - MORNING The neighbor’s dog is barking. Jim’s eyes snap open. He sits up with purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s a disaster area. Jim enters and paints another yellow layer. He pees indiscriminately, all over the floor, the toilet, the walls...whatever. He exits without flushing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim strolls in wearing sweats and a wife beater. He grabs a stick of butter from the fridge. Takes a box of Strawberry Nestle’s® Quick from the cabinet. He jams the butter in the Quick and takes a bite. And that shit is good. While he eats his strawberry butter, Jim collects various wash rags from his kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim is now wearing a T-shirt over the wife beater, and he’s holding a pile of other shirts and pants. He puts them on, layer after layer. Then he starts wrapping his hands with the rags.  58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim bangs on the door, wrapped in cotton armor. The Gay Neighbor answers.

dialogues.speaker: THE GAY NEIGHBOR
dialogues.text: Morning, Jim. What’s with the--

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Where is he? In the back?

dialogues.speaker: THE GAY NEIGHBOR
dialogues.text: Who? Jim pushes past him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim freezes when he sees...

dialogues.speaker: AN ENTIRE WALL COVERED FLOOR TO CEILING WITH FRAMED
dialogues.text: PHOTOS OF THE GAY NEIGHBOR’S DOG... FUCKING. Dozens of pictures of Hoag mounting other dogs. Hundreds of them really. Poodles and Schnauzers, Shih-Tzus and Beagles, all getting pounded from behind. Tiny Dachshunds and Chihuahuas are barely visible beneath Hoag’s massive chest. The Shepherds and Labradors look sad. The Dobermans look frightened. There are many emotions, because there are so many pictures of so many dogs getting fucked. And the centerpiece of the collection is photo of the Gay Neighbor giving a big thumbs up as Hoagie piledrives a defeated Great Dane.

dialogues.speaker: THE GAY NEIGHBOR
dialogues.text: (self-conscious) Please don’t think I’m weird. It’s a long story. Jim stares at him. Long silence.

dialogues.speaker: THE GAY NEIGHBOR
dialogues.text: I’m out of my mind...you know that, right? Jim shakes it off and marches past him.  59. EXT. THE GAY NEIGHBOR’S BACKYARD - CONTINUOUS 160 pounds of four-legged, cocksucking, Bull Mastiff yanks against his spiked chain, crazed, frothing. This is a very serious dog. Jim takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (without looking back) Let him off. The Gay Neighbor moves from behind Jim, and approaches his dog. He seems a bit frightened by his own beast.

dialogues.speaker: THE GAY NEIGHBOR
dialogues.text: Jim, I can’t let him off. Look at him.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: This has to happen.

dialogues.speaker: THE GAY NEIGHBOR
dialogues.text: Do you understand you’re on his property? Hoagie is a full bred Bull Mastiff, he’1l kill you, man. The dog snarls, raging against his restraints.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: So be it. Let him off. The Gay Neighbor reaches for Hoag’s collar. Looks at Jim one last time.

dialogues.speaker: THE GAY NEIGHBOR
dialogues.text: Are you sure, Jim? Jim nods. The Gay Neighbor releases Hoag. Hoag charges at Jim, leaps... Jim throws up his arms just in time to protect his throat, but the savage animal knocks him to the ground. Hoag sets upon Jim with a ferocity that is primal. Jim can do little more than offer his limbs to the whirlwind of fangs.

dialogues.speaker: OH GOD
dialogues.text: The dog locks onto Jim’s calf. Hoag shakes violently, tearing off strips of bloody flesh. Well not flesh exactly, it’s just cloth soaked with Jim's blood.  60. Jim flails for a large grilling fork sitting next to a barbecue grill.

dialogues.speaker: THE GAY NEIGHBOR
dialogues.text: (subtitled; speaks in Japanese) Hoag, he's going for the fork! The dog advances to the back of Jim’s neck and locks on. This could be the death of Jim.

dialogues.speaker: OH GOD
dialogues.text: But Jim has the fork. With all his might he shoves the fork into Hoag’s back. Hoag YELPS. Jim tries to scramble to his feet but falls due to the severe wound on his calf. Blood pours out of his pant cuff. He’1l die soon.

dialogues.speaker: THE GAY NEIGHBOR
dialogues.text: Hoag, he's lost tremendous blood. You must sweep the leg...NOW! Despite a fork protruding from Hoag’s back, the animal is in top form. Again it gets airborne... ON JIM —- SLOW MOTION: Hoag flies through the air with a clear line to Jim's throat. But at the last second--BAMN!, Jim clocks him with a round house punch to the head. ROB’S HOUSE - LATER Jim slaps the car into park, causing it to lurch. He gets out. Doesn’t bother to close the door.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: You wouldn't... Rebecca sprints inside the house. Jim sprints for his car. Fighting a dog is one thing, fighting Junior is...suicide. INT./ EXT. JIM’S BMW - CONTINUOUS He fumbles with the keys. Even over the horn he hears...

dialogues.speaker: DAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAADDY

dialogues.speaker: FUCK

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: (bellowing)

dialogues.speaker: JIM SLAMS IT INTO DRIVE --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only the dregs are here. Maureen sits waiting, watching the front door. It opens... The sound of Jim’s car horn floods in behind him as he enters. He sees Maureen, approaches like he’s got something to say.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Where’s Larry? I need to talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN

dialogues.text: That’s probably a bad idea... He sniffs...no odor...so he takes a seat.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: You know, I was gonna decline cause I thought the stench would be too stomach churning, but I must say... you're surprisingly fresh. She smiles with pride.

dialogues.text: Yeah. It’s these charcoal-lined panties I bought. As a surprise for Larry. Now Jim and Maureen both stare at the door. Every time it opens, the car horn spills in, annoying the patrons. They sit in silence for a long awkward moment.

dialogues.text: Thank God you're here, Larry. I fucked Olivia and it was great, but it really sucked and I--

JIM’S LIVING ROOM - 2:58 A.M Jim sits in the dark, lost and alone. He’s reached the end of his rope. His past life is destroyed, there is no future, there is just purgatory. Unless... He picks up the remote. The television splashes the darkness with shifting light. Jim leans forward, surfing the channels with urgency.

dialogues.text: Clogged with doughy tourists bulging out of their bathing suits. A long line of cars waiting to park snakes out onto the main road. With no regard for anyone, the Beamer swerves in front of an old lady and skids to a stop across the last two handicap spaces. He’s down to his underwear as he snatches a newspaper out of the PARKING ATTENDANT'S hand and buck naked by the time he squats into the trash can to take a shit. It’s a scene, man. The STUCK CAR HORN in the background is accented by a short GRUNT of relief as Jim finishes. He struggles to get out of the can, then pushes past the horrified crowd, bee-lining for the ocean. Naked as a jaybird, he strides purposefully into the cold waters of the Atlantic. The wailing CAR HORN rises in CRESCENDO as we...

dialogues.text: Unbelievable... That’s it. Jim gives up. He sits cross-legged. After a moment, he just lies back. Then...he squints. Jim turns around, and sonuvabitch... The MAGNIFICENT TUNNEL OF LIGHT that he missed before is right there.

dialogues.text: Get the fuck outta here... Jim stands and walks tentatively towards the light. CLOSE ON A POT OF BOILING WATER FOR NO GOOD REASON... +.-no good reason whatsoever. dialogues.text: All American superstar, THOMAS DOUGLAS CRUISE. Star of Risky Business, the Mission: Impossible series, and most recently, the comedy super-smash BALLS OUT.

dialogues.text: Tom Cruise is in his lavish helicopter teaching his personal chef BASKERVILLE how to make hot dogs to perfection. Always perfection.  93.

dialogues.speaker: BASKERVILLE
dialogues.text: Mr. Cruise, I understand.

dialogues.speaker: TOM CRUISE
dialogues.text: I’ve measured the water precisely to allow the exposed skin of these Oscar Meyer® granddaddy franks to harden to perfection. (a beat to build up intensity) Always perfection. Tom Cruise stares into Baskerville’s soul until Baskerville averts his eyes.

dialogues.text: Baskerville! The chef turns to face his master.

dialogues.speaker: TOM CRUISE, (CONT'D)

dialogues.text: Tom Cruise thrusts himself inside. He locks eyes with his PILOT and CO-PILOT. Points his fingers at them with ferocity, just to let them know who the fuck he is, then says...

dialogues.text: What is it? What is happening at this precise moment? His pilot squints. Points out to the ocean below...

dialogues.speaker: TOM CRUISE
dialogues.text: Danger, huh? (points in their faces to let them know who the fuck he is) I hate danger. Danger is a fucking asshole! Tom Cruise storms out, ready for action.

dialogues.text: Tom Cruise grabs a rope, ties it around his leg, ready to jump.

dialogues.text: Tom Cruise, that’s not the way you tie--

dialogues.speaker: TOM CRUISE
dialogues.text: I know that, Baskerville. But I don’t have time to do the research. Tom yanks open the bay door. He jumps. Backwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Cruise falls, arms out, Christlike. Better still, Tom Cruise-like. His eyes are closed for maximum intensity. But gradually, his perfect form is perverted by factors like gravity and the heavy rotor wash that causes the rope to entangle his body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About five feet above the surface, Tom Cruise’s rope yanks taut, caught around his left arm and ankle...

dialogues.speaker: AAAHHHH
dialogues.text: Both primary joints, shoulder and hip, are violently dislocated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baskerville looks down, sees his master screaming in agony.  95.

dialogues.speaker: TOM CRUISE
dialogues.text: (screams up) Baskerville! Oh, God! Baskerville, I’m in tremendous pain!

dialogues.speaker: BASKERVILLE
dialogues.text: I‘ll bring you back up. Let me--

dialogues.speaker: TOM CRUISE
dialogues.text: No! NO! Danger cannot win. Not this time. This time I make danger MY bitch! (with steely-eyed intensity) Lower me.

dialogues.speaker: BASKERVILLE
dialogues.text: (to himself) Goddamn you. Goddamn you, you magnificent bastard. He lowers the rope and Tom Cruise splashes face first into the mighty Atlantic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Cruise is drowning. He’s tangled in rope with half his body immobilized and he’s drowning. Jim is nearby. Tom Cruise cringes in agony as he valiantly swims towards him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baskerville and the CO-PILOT scan the ocean below, searching for any sign of their heroic employer. Then they see it... Tom Cruise’s hand gives the thumbs-up from beneath the very ocean that is killing him. They hit the button on an electric winch. It’s winchy thing turns...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Cruise uses his one good arm to clasp around Jim’s throat in a choke hold. As the rope pulls tight...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He dangles, hips and shoulders being ripped further from their sockets by the added weight of Jim, who, if he’s not already dead, is surely being strangled to death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Although severely damaged, Tom Cruise fights to save Jim’s life, beating on his chest.

dialogues.speaker: TOM CRUISE
dialogues.text: Don’t you die on me, man. You've never backed away from a fight in your life, you bitch! Fight... (smacks Jim) Fight! (smacks Baskerville)

dialogues.speaker: FIGHT
dialogues.text: Jim coughs.

dialogues.speaker: BASKERVILLE
dialogues.text: He’s alive! Tom Cruise staggers over to a seat, collapses into it, exhausted. Baskerville is horrified when he notices...

dialogues.speaker: BASKERVILLE
dialogues.text: Master! Your...your leg... Tom Cruise’s left arm and leg hang slack, flopped at weird angles. Tom Cruise hops up on his one good leg and slams his hip back into socket with a sickening pop. He lets loose an intense groan accompanied by tears and snot. Now for the shoulder. The same thing. Another groan. More tears and snot. Tom falls to his knees, then looks up at Jim with damp eyes, burning with full intensity. Jim’s face is calm. He looks at the man who saved him. Everything leading up to this moment now makes sense.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I’ve finally seen the light. I finally understand what you were talking about.  97.

dialogues.speaker: JIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I used to think that sometimes you gotta say what the fuck--or whatever, that that was the right thing to do. But now I know, Tom Cruise. I know that it was the wrong movie.

dialogues.speaker: BASKERVILLE
dialogues.text: (heartfelt) I too lived my life out of place. Years ago, I was all Days of Thunder until I nearly killed a man. And when I saw Cocktail, I became even more confused. But then, when I realized that The Outsiders and Far and Away were--

dialogues.speaker: TOM CRUISE
dialogues.text: ENOUGH! This man has finally gotten out of his own way, and you’re confusing him with your imprecise bullshit. BEGONE! He points to the cockpit. Baskerville skulks off. Tom Cruise looks at Jim. Intensely.

dialogues.speaker: TOM CRUISE
dialogues.text: Look, if there’s one thing I've learned having climbed a thousand mountains, it’s that... (one last beam of intensity) You’ve gotta learn to live with what you are, my friend. Jim contemplates this. It makes hella-sense to him.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Fuck yeah I do. They shake hands. Tom Cruise yanks him into a manly embrace and we FREEZE FRAME triumphantly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upon golden sun we set hither. Jim walks toward us wearing Baskerville’s pristine white chef’s uniform (with matching hat). He’s serene as he breezes right past the still blaring BMW. Here he goes (again) on his own. Going down the only road he’s ever known.  98. EXT. JIM’S APARTMENT - DUSK Jim enters the house. Beat. He exits and heads around back to his dusty SPORTY KIA SPECTRUM (WITH RACING STRIPE). Jim smiles as he climbs into it and fires it up. EXT. ROB’S GARAGE - EVENING Rob is packing up his shit, forlorn. Jim approaches. Notices Rob’s array of SEAL HOOKS lined against the wall. Each more horrendous in design than the next. Rob begins packing his hooks into a stylish attache’ case, one at a time.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: What are you doing, Rob?

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: What does it look like I’m doing? I’m packing my shit. Jim is calmer than Lake Placid on a placid day.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Do you think what you’re doing is smart?

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: I don’t know if it’s smart, but I know I’1l be gone. And that’s a start.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Why are you doing this? Rob stops packing. Sets down a disturbingly bloodstained gaff.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: I’m doing it because of you. Jim remains silent.

dialogues.speaker: ROB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I saw the light, Jim. I mean, there’s a whole world out there that doesn’t involve the shit I have to deal with here. He waits for Jim to respond, but Jim remains silent.  99.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Sure, I‘ll miss her. And the boy. But you know what? There’s more to life than this domesticated bullshit, right? Right? Jim slowly shakes his head, ‘no’. Rob is crestfallen.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: But how can you say that, Jim? After all you’ve been through and all of the glorious things you've achieved for yourself in these last two weeks, how can you honestly say that?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Because it’s the truth. Don’t make the mistakes that I made, Rob. Don’t give up what you’ve got for what will never be. (deep) Jim grabs Rob by the shoulders, as a father would, and stares into his soul with Cruise-like intensity.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: A wise man once spoke to me, Rob. And he told me something really important, something I’d like to share with you.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: I’m listening. Jim takes a deep cleansing breath and closes his eyes as he recalls the words that changed his life...

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: He said, “Don’t be like these birds, Jimberly. Don’t be out at sea when there’s biscuits at home. On the Titanic.” (fucking deep) Jim opens his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: And you know what? He was right. I heard him, but I was just too proud to listen. Holy fucking shit. The simple truth of the Black Bum’s words and Jim’s understanding of them hits Rob like a ton of bricks.  100.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: (rocked to the core) My God, you’re right. You're so...right, Jim. What am I doing? (realizing) Oh God, what have I done? Without warning, the door from inside opens and the hulking mass that is JUNIOR fills the doorway. Beneath the rage and retardation, lies the soul of a gentle mongoloid. And it is that gentle beast who stares into his stepfather’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: Moon? Rob can’t help but be overcome with emotion.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: (plaintive) Moon? A single tear slides down Rob’s cheek as his face opens into a loving smile.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Moon, Junior. Moon. Rob rushes to Junior and they embrace. The word “step” evaporates from their relationship forever. Just then Rebecca appears in the doorway, love and forgiveness filling her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: REBECCA
dialogues.text: Awww, my boys. Rebecca joins her family in a three-way hug. The veneer of domestic bliss has been restored. A peaceful wind blows through Jim’s hair. The wind of change. Jim walks off into the night like Kang in “Kung Fu.” EXT. LARRY’S HOVEL - NIGHT Jim rings the door bell. He gets some unknown gunk on his finger. Wipes it off just as Larry answers.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Jim, get out of here. I will fucking kill you, so get out of here.  Beat. 101.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (calm) I’m sorry, Larry.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: No. Fuck you and your stupid chef costume. What are you a chef? A fucking cook? Get off my porch, you maker of food!

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I really am sorry.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: She won’t answer the phone. I can’t even tell her the very things you just said to me. And it’s because of you.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: You fucked up my shit, Jim.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Larry, I was so focused on myself and my needs that I didn’t give a hot fuck about yours.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yeah. That was crazy, huh? We were all popping melons, and shit. (thinks to himself) Remember that time Rob hit that hillbilly with the pizza?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: You mean last week?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Those were good times, huh? Good times...

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Times can be good again, Larry. Larry is shocked to see Maureen approaching. But why is he surprised?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Maureen?  102. He licks his finger and holds it up - no prevailing winds. He sniffs the air repeatedly.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: How were you able to...? He kneels and takes in a good whiff at crotch level.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Nothing!

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: I did some research, Larry. It’s gone. Larry, still kneeling, realizes...

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Well, hell, while I’m down here... Maureen instantly turns giddy. She knows what he’s about to ask. He takes her hand in his...

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Maureen Duplexis Nassoon? Will you be my bottom chick?

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: No more redheads?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: No more blondes either. Just me and you and a dog named Boo. Maureen is so emotional that she can’t speak. All she can do is nod her head ‘yes’. Larry takes her in his arms and tongues her down with both passion and love.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (re: his massive erection) Look at that, baby. Just look at it. No Viagra®. That’s all you. Maureen smiles. She turns to Jim and grabs him up in a hug.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Thank you, Jim! Thank you for reuniting us! Jim smiles warmly.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Riunite™ on ice...  103.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN AND LARRY
dialogues.text: (giving the thumbs up) ..-that’s nice! FREEZE FRAME on the thumbs up, a snapshot of happiness and joy that could and should be framed and hung in the National Gallery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An endless sea of cubicles filled with people doing things and saying things we couldn’t care less about. Except for Schooley and McCorkle, who are wasting time in the corner. Schooley nonchalantly carries a BABY by its ankle. The baby doesn’t seem to mind.

dialogues.speaker: MCCORKLE
dialogues.text: Cute kid.

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOLEY
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: MCCORKLE
dialogues.text: Where’d you get it?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOLEY
dialogues.text: I bought it.

dialogues.speaker: MCCORKLE
dialogues.text: You bought it?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOLEY
dialogues.text: Yeah. From some Jamaicans.

dialogues.speaker: MCCORKLE
dialogues.text: How the fuck did you buy a white baby from some Jamaicans?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOLEY
dialogues.text: I gave them a kilogram. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: MCCORKLE
dialogues.text: You can get a kid for one kilo?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOLEY
dialogues.text: Yep. And I did. (then) Wanna thumb its soft spot?  104.

dialogues.speaker: MCCORKLE
dialogues.text: Of course I do. As Schooley holds out the baby and McCorkle moves in, our attention shifts to the door. The theme from AN OFFICER AND A GENTLEMAN SWELLS as Jim, still wearing Baskerville’s gleaming white chef’s uniform, enters the building and strides across the office with purpose. All heads turn as he closes in on Jill’s cubicle... INT. JILL’S CUBICLE - CONTINUOUS Jill stands, her back to the entrance, feeding documents into a paper shredder. Jim slides up from behind her and kisses her on the neck. Jill turns, reacts with pleasant surprise as she removes the earplugs from her ears. Jim pulls her close and kisses her with a heretofore unseen gusto. They separate, staring lovingly into each other’s eyes. The music RISES IN CRESCENDO and...

dialogues.speaker: WA-PAPP
dialogues.text: She wallops Jim square in the nose, sending him tumbling backward on his ass. Blood cascades from his busted snout, saturating his white uniform.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Fuck you, Jim Simmers. Fuck you in your clammy white ass!

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (gurgling through blood) Jill...

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: I don’t know who you think I am, but I am not the kind of girl who you can shit all over and then expect to get weak in the knees just because you come waltzing in here in a sexy uniform.. Jim struggles to get his feet.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Jill... She kicks him back down on his ass, then wipes her bloody shoe on his pants.  105.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: I may not have a perfect ass or a magical hoo-hoo, but I have self- respect. I have respect, Jim. For my SELF!

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Jill... Jim once again tries to stand, dizzy from blood loss.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: And just because you’ve finally had a spiritual reawakening, don’t think that... Jim clasps a hand over Jill’s mouth.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Just shut up and listen. No more games. You’re the one that I want, Jill. You're the eight raspberries in my cereal. The heavy whipping cream in my Munter’s Brown Roast. The Strawberry Quick™ on my butter stick. Jim gazes longingly into her violet eyes

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I’ve known this, in my heart, since the first day we met, but I was too stupid to understand it. Until now. He removes his hand from her mouth and takes her face in his hands. Jill is

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I love you, Jill. And I mean it. And I believe we are meant to try and see if we can be together and then be okay with it if it doesn’t work out. apoplectic.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Wow. I think I just threw up in my vagina. Just a chunky little bit.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I just hope it was from the heart. She grabs Jim’s bloody face and mashes it against her own in a disgustingly pure yet potentially infectious kiss. Jim scoops her off of her feet and...  106.

dialogues.speaker: JOE COCKER
dialogues.text: (singing) Where the eagles cry, on a mountain high...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..-carries her out of her cubicle and across the floor of the main office. INTERCUT with REACTION SHOTS of all the people we haven’t seen for, like, half the movie or more:

dialogues.speaker: CO-WORKER 2
dialogues.text: drops his bagel, shocked.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WHITEMAN
dialogues.text: smiles, nods in approval.

dialogues.speaker: BLAH-BLAH
dialogues.text: pumps his fist ‘right ON’!

dialogues.speaker: BLAKE HENDERSON
dialogues.text: dressed in overalls, peering in the window from behind a push mower. He can’t help but smile. And finally...

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: looking down from the second tier. After a moment, she can’t help but collapse into a beaming smile.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: (calling out) Way to go, Paula! She begins to clap...

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Way to go! The office erupts in APPLAUSE. We follow Jim as he carries Jill toward the exit. Just as they are framed in the warm glow of the sun spilling through the door, Jill reaches up and grabs the chef’s hat from Jim’s head and gingerly places it on her own head.  107. Jill smiles through the blood on her face. Jim matches her smile and... FREEZE FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: YEAH
dialogues.text: And with that, we...

dialogues.speaker: FADE THE FUCK OUT
